When B calls C, is B's method trivial? See the JUnit FAQ for details on wha=
t I mean by that. If B's method is trivial, then testing B only tests C and=
 nothing else, so I wouldn't bother writing the test. If B's method takes p=
arameters and passes them to C, then B's method still cannot break: only th=
e methods that call B's method and C could break, so test those.

I would u=
se the same approach for the relationship between A and B.

If B's method i=
s not trivial, then as soon as you feel the pain of duplicated tests mock t=
he behavior in C that B calls and use that mock behavior in the test. This =
allows you to test B in isolation from any defects in C.

I hope this helps=
.
